channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Wolfram, a Search Engine, Finds Answers Within Itself
item.description: Wolfram Alpha Pro’s creator wants his “computational knowledge engine” to appeal to more than math and science enthusiasts.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE LOHR

item.title: Media Decoder Blog: Verizon Teaming With Redbox for DVD and Streaming Service
item.description: The two companies will combine to try to give customers more access to video on the Web, and possibly position the new venture as an alternative to Netflix.
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK

item.title: Art Review: VIP Art Fair 2.0 Is Virtual, Modeled on the Traditional
item.media:description: VIP Art Fair 2.0“O Cowboy” (2010), by Beatriz Milhazes is among the works showing at this virtual exposition.
item.description: Art Fair 2.0 takes a second stab at the virtual exhibition (and the Web site runs more smoothly this year).
item.dc:creator: By MARTHA SCHWENDENER

item.title: Facebook’s Mobility Challenge
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook plan to experiment with mobile advertising, including inserting so-called sponsored stories into users' update streams.
item.description: Although more than half of its 845 million members log into Facebook on a mobile device, the company has not yet found a way to make real money from that use.
item.dc:creator: By JENNA WORTHAM

item.title: Cancer Center, in Suit, Claims Ex-Official Took Research
item.media:description: Dr. Craig B. Thompson, now of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, is being sued.
item.description: The president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Dr. Craig B. Thompson, is in a billion-dollar dispute with his former workplace over accusations that he walked away with research.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: A New Question of Internet Freedom
item.media:description: In January, lawmakers in Poland held up masks to protest the ratifying of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement.
item.description: European activists are hoping to stop the international Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement, which they say will erode Internet freedom and stifle innovation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Bits Blog: Start-Up Nicira Plans to Disrupt Networking Giants
item.description: A small company called Nicira and a few other scrappy players are pursuing what is called software-defined networking.
item.dc:creator: By QUENTIN HARDY

item.title: Raw Data: Austrian Law Student Faces Down Facebook
item.media:description: Max Schrems, 24, an Austrian law student, is leading a campaign in Europe against Facebook's use of personal data.
item.description: Max Schrems's crusade against the information collected by the social network has become a cause célèbre in parts of Europe, looming over the company as it prepares to go public.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN J. O'BRIEN

item.title: Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook, Staying on Message
item.media:description: Facebook's No. 2 executive, Sheryl Sandberg, will reap a fortune in its stock offering. And she hasn't stopped telling the world how women should take responsibility for their careers.
item.description: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s No. 2 executive, considers herself a role model for women. But her call isn’t simply about mentoring and empowering; it’s also a business strategy.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: Slipstream: Employers and Brands Use Gaming to Gauge Engagement
item.description: More companies are turning to gamification — offering games that let their customers win points for certain activities — as a way to build both loyalty and a trove of data.
item.dc:creator: By NATASHA SINGER

item.title: In Silicon Valley, Socks Make the Tech Entrepreneur
item.media:description: Some say the craze took hold because patterned socks are an acceptable shot of flair in a dressed-down culture.
item.media:credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
item.description: In Silicon Valley, wearing flashy socks is more than an expression of your personality. It signals that you are part of the in crowd.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and NICK BILTON

item.title: Digital Domain: On HealthTap, Advice for You and Points for Doctors
item.media:description: On the HealthTap Web site, users can seek all kinds of free medical advice, and doctors can earn recognition and whimsical “awards” for providing the answers.
item.description: On HealthTap, an interactive Web site, users can ask for medical advice, and doctors can gain whimsical “awards” for their answers.
item.dc:creator: By RANDALL STROSS

item.title: Video Games: Curt Schilling, Former Red Sox Pitcher, Makes Video Games
item.media:description: R. A. Salvatore, left, and the former Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, chairman of the video game company 38 Studios.
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.description: Curt Schilling, the former Boston Red Sox pitcher, left baseball to start 38 Studios, a video game company, maker of Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning.
item.dc:creator: By ETHAN GILSDORF

item.title: E.U. Presses Google to Delay Privacy Policy Changes
item.media:description: Viviane Reding is the European Union justice commissioner.
item.description: Viviane Reding, the European Union justice commissioner, is pressing Google to halt changes to its privacy policies while the implications for personal data protection are being explored.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: F.B.I. Admits Hacker Group’s Eavesdropping
item.description: The group known as Anonymous listened in on a call between the bureau, Scotland Yard and other foreign police agencies about their joint investigation of the group and its allies.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: Steve Appleton, Micron Technology C.E.O., Dies in Plane Crash
item.description: Steve Appleton, whose death was considered a major loss for the struggling company, was piloting the small craft in Boise, Idaho.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Zuckerberg’s Big Tax Bill May Benefit Facebook
item.media:description: Facebook’s corporate headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg plans to exercise stock options with an estimated value of $5 billion ahead of Facebook’s initial public offering, which will translate into a big tax benefit for the company.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

item.title: DealBook Column: Those Millions on Facebook? Some May Not Actually Visit
item.description: "Active users" add up in Facebook's prospectus, but some of those clicks aren't on the Web site.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

item.title: Disruptions: Disruptions: Facebook Users Ask, 'Where's Our Cut?'
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive officer and founder of Facebook, spoke at a Facebook conference in September.
item.description: Without the free content created by its 850 million users, Facebook would surely not be on the verge of a multibillion-dollar initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: By NICK BILTON

item.title: The Media Equation: At BuzzFeed, the Significant and the Silly
item.media:description: Jonah Peretti, left, creator of BuzzFeed, and Ben Smith, its new editor in chief. The site tries to offer material that will be passed along, pulling more visitors to the site.
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times
item.description: The Web site is trying for pollination: providing the kind of content that will have visitors passing along links from one person to the next, that will in turn bring them around to BuzzFeed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR

item.title: Opinion: The Death of the Cyberflâneur
item.description: Today’s Internet is a place for getting things done, pushing aside the cyberflâneur — the heir to the flâneur culture of 19th-century France.
item.dc:creator: By EVGENY MOROZOV

item.title: Gray Matter: Is GPS All in Our Heads?
item.description: Relying on GPS devices can erode our ability to develop mental maps.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA FRANKENSTEIN

item.title: Strategies: I.P.O. Euphoria, Without Much Memory — Strategies
item.description: Amid the Wall Street excitement over Facebook’s planned initial public offering, it may be a good time to take a look at I.P.O. history.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF SOMMER

item.title: With Filters, Photos Take On Multiple Identities
item.media:description: The Graphic Novel filter is meant to simulate the look from a hand illustrated novel.
item.description: Photo filtering software is becoming more sophisticated, and some photographers share filters they have created themselves.
item.dc:creator: By PETER WAYNER

item.title: App Smart: Scanner Apps Make Digital Versions of Paper Documents
item.media:description: The JotNot Scanner Pro app for iPhone.
item.description: Apps for Apple and Android phones let a user take a photo of a document and turn it into a PDF that can be exported or printed.
item.dc:creator: By BOB TEDESCHI

item.title: Gadgetwise Blog: Q&A: Backup Options for iTunes
item.description: How to back up iTunes files locally.
item.dc:creator: By J.D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Gadgetwise Blog: Q&A: Finding a Phone's Android Version
item.description: How to check to see which version of Android your handset is running.
item.dc:creator: By J.D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Gadgetwise Blog: A Compact Camera Whose Lens Isn't
item.description: Nikon has announced nine new Coolpix cameras, including the P510, which has a zoom that goes from the equivalent of a 24-millimeter wide angle to a 1,000-millimeter telephoto.
item.dc:creator: By ROY FURCHGOTT
